clinicalDescription: Overview: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) describes the gradual loss of kidney function. Presentation: Symptoms are non-specific and develop slowly. Symptoms may include fatigue, hypertension, electrolyte imbalances, dyspnea and abnormal heart rhythm.Assessment: CKD is defined by the presence of kidney damage or eGFR < 60 mL/min for three or more months.Plan: Management of CKD includes treatment of reversible causes of disease (e.g. diabetes) and complications of renal failure, adjusting drug dosing according to patient's eGFR, and dialysis or kidney transplant in certain patients.Prognosis: Patients with CKD can live healthy lives with adequate treatment of disease complications; however, patients with Stage IV CKD may deteriorate quickly leading to significant morbidity and mortality.
